At that time, in the assembly, there was the youth Sudatta-varabhadra, who rose from his seat, put his palms together, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How does one see the cause of form?
How does one see the cause of desire?ğŸ”½How does one see the cause of views?
How does one see the cause of clinging to precepts and practices?
The Buddha told Sudatta:
The wise see the realm of the wise, the foolish see the realm of the foolish.

The wise see all beautiful and attractive forms, and know them to be filthy and evil, merely pieces of flesh, sinews, bones, pus, blood, large and small vessels, large and small intestines, phlegm, brain membranes, kidneys, heart, spleen, gall, liver, lungs, stomach, raw and cooked viscera, yellow liquid, nasal mucus, hair, beard, body hair, nails, feces and urine, wrapped in thin skin, impure and exposed, frightening and disgusting.
All forms are born from the four great elements, which are the causes of form.
Candrasiddhi!

Just as parents give birth to the body, the solidity of the body is the earth element, the moisture is the water element, the warmth is the fire element, and the movement is the wind element. The awareness, thoughts, and the realms of sound, smell, taste, touch, etc. are all consciousness.
The youth Candrasiddhi addressed the Buddha again, saying:
World-Honored One!
When one is about to die, how does consciousness abandon the body?
How does consciousness move the body?
How does consciousness know that it is now abandoning this body?
The Buddha told Candrasiddhi:
Beings, according to their karma, receive retribution. Consciousness flows and continues, sustaining the body without interruption.
When the allotted time is up and the retribution ends, consciousness abandons the body and moves according to karma to receive [the next life].
It is like mixing water and milk and boiling them. By the power of the heat, the milk, water, and fat are each dispersed.
In this way, Candrasiddhi!
When the life of a sentient being ends, by the power of karma, the body and consciousness, as well as the sense bases and elements, each disperse.
Consciousness serves as the basis, taking the dharma realm and thoughts of the dharma realm, along with good and evil karma, to receive other retributions.
Candrasiddhi!
It is like the great auspicious ghee, which is made by combining the flavors, powers, and medicinal effects of various fine medicines.

The great auspicious ghee abandons the nature of ordinary ghee, holds the power of the fine medicines, and uses the six flavors of bitter, pungent, sour, salty, astringent, and sweet to nourish the human body, then it gives off color, smell, and taste to the human body.
Consciousness abandons this body, holds good and evil karma, and the fruits of the dharmas, and transfers to receive other retributions in the same way.
Candrasiddhi!
The substance of ghee is like the body, and various medicines are combined to make great auspiciousness.
It is like various dharmas and various faculties being combined to form karma, and various medicine flavors and touches nourishing ghee.

It is like how karma nourishes consciousness. If one takes great auspicious and wholesome medicine, one's complexion becomes full and lustrous, one's appearance is beautiful, and one is peaceful and free from illness. It is like how wholesome things nourish consciousness and one obtains the reward of happiness.

If one takes poison in violation of the Dharma, one's facial complexion changes to an evil and ashen color, and one's complexion becomes as white as dead earth. It is like how evil things nourish consciousness and one obtains the retribution of suffering.
Candrasiddhi!
Auspicious, wholesome, precious medicine has no hands, feet, or eyes, yet it can take good medicine, color, fragrance, flavor, and potency.

Consciousness is also like this. It takes the dharma realm, sensation, and wholesome karma, abandons this bodily realm, and receives the intermediate existence. It obtains the wonderful thoughts of the heavens and sees the sixteen hells of the six desire heavens. It sees its own body with dignified hands and feet and beautiful faculties, and sees the discarded corpse, saying This is my previous body.

It also sees the lofty and excellent heavenly palace with wonderful characteristics, adorned with various flowers, fruits, plants, trees, vines, and creepers. The light is radiant, like newly refined gold adorned with various treasures.
Having seen this, their minds are greatly delighted, and due to this great joy and love, consciousness then attaches to it.
This person of good karma, when abandoning this body and receiving another body, is at ease and without suffering, like a rider who abandons one horse and mounts another.
It is like a strong man who is fully equipped with martial skills, seeing the enemy troops approaching, he dons solid armor, mounts his swift horse, and goes forth without fear.

In the same way, consciousness, aided by the wholesome roots, abandons the in-and-out breath, leaves the realms and sense bases, and enters the body, transitioning to experience supreme bliss, and is born among the BrahmakÄya gods up to the highest heaven.

In the end times, among the defiled beings, they are foolish and ignorant, not knowing good from evil. They are unable to discern what is good or not good, what is ripe or not ripe, and are confused, revolving in the sufferings of birth and death.
The Buddha told Prince MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya:
The TathÄgata's true Dharma is difficult to encounter and difficult to obtain.

In the past, for half a verse, I climbed a mountain, threw myself off, and abandoned my body and life. For the sake of seeking the true Dharma, I went through countless hundreds of thousands of myriads of difficulties and hardships.

Prince MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya said to the Buddha:

What are the characteristics of consciousness?
Please explain them to me.

It is like a person's reflection appearing in the water. This reflection cannot be grasped, and it cannot be distinguished as existent or non-existent. It is like the form of a straw dog, like the reflection of thirst.
Prince MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-Å›Ästra said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
What is thirst?
The Buddha said:
It is like a person facing a pleasing color, and the eye faculty turns towards it, which is called thirst.
It is like holding up a bright mirror to see one's own face. If one moves away from the mirror, the face will not appear.
The movement of consciousness is also like this. The forms of good and evil karma and the images of consciousness are all invisible.
It is like a person who is born blind. They do not know the sun, the rising and setting of the sun, the day and night, or the light and darkness.
Consciousness is unable to see in the same way. Thirst, sensation, perception, and memory in the body are all invisible.
The various great elements, sense bases, and aggregates of the body are all consciousness.

All physical forms, such as eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body, as well as sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, and also the formless mind that experiences suffering and pleasure, are also consciousness.
Great Medicine!
Just as a person's tongue can taste sweet, bitter, pungent, sour, salty, and astringent flavors, distinguishing all six tastes.
The tongue and the food both have form and color, but the flavors are formless.
Also, due to the bones, marrow, flesh, and blood of the body, one experiences various sensations. The bones and so forth have form, but the sensations are formless.
The fruits of meritorious and non-meritorious karma are also like this.
At that time, the youth SubÄhu, the foremost of the True Sons, bowed at the Buddha's feet and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Can this consciousness be seen as meritorious or non-meritorious?
The Buddha said:
Listen well.
It cannot be seen by one who has not yet seen the truth.
Consciousness cannot be seen, unlike an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of the hand, and consciousness is not within the eyes and so forth.
If consciousness were within the eyes and so forth, then by splitting open the eyes and so forth one should be able to see consciousness.
Xianhu!
The Buddhas of the Ganges sands see consciousness as formless, and I also see consciousness in the same way as formless.
Consciousness is not something that ordinary foolish people can see, but it is only revealed through metaphors.
Xianhu!
If you wish to know the sins and merits of consciousness, you should now listen.
It is like a person who is possessed by various celestial spirits, gandharvas, and so forth, as well as by the ghosts and spirits of sekhas and so forth. Xianhu!
What do you think?
As for being possessed by the celestial spirits and so forth, can the essence of that possession be found and seen within the body?
Xianhu addressed the Buddha, saying:
No, World-Honored One!
The gods and ghosts that possess people have no form or shape, and cannot be seen inside or outside the body.
Virtuous Protector!

Those possessed by the great gods with superior blessings should use good incense, flowers, burn various famous incense, and offer fragrant and delicious food. All the offerings should be fragrant and clean.

In this way, if the consciousness is nourished by blessings, one will obtain the fruits of noble status and happiness, either as a human king, a prime minister, a person of great prestige, one with wealth and freedom, a leader, a great merchant, or one who attains a heavenly body and experiences the superior fruits of heaven. Because the consciousness is nourished by blessings, the body obtains the reward of happiness.
Just as those possessed by the gods with superior blessings obtain superior and wonderful flowers, incense, fragrant and delicious food, and immediately become joyful, and the sick become well.
Now, obtaining noble status, great wealth and freedom, one should know that this is all due to the consciousness being nourished by blessings and the body obtaining the reward of happiness.
Xianhu!
Those who are possessed by the evil ghosts such as Putana will love filthy, rotten, and disgusting things, and by offering these to them, they will be happy and cured.
By the power of the ghosts, they will follow the ghosts' desires and love impure, foul, and rotten filth.

The consciousness nourished by sin is also like this. It may be born in poverty, as a hungry ghost, or in various evil realms that eat filth and other animals. Due to the consciousness nourished by sin, the body will experience the bitter fruits.
Xianhu!
The superior gods have a body that is possessed by them, which is formless and shapeless, yet receives various pure offerings.
The consciousness nourished by blessings, receiving the superior blissful rewards, is also like this.
The evil ghosts such as Putana, when possessing others, will cause them to receive impure and foul food and drink.
The consciousness nourished by sinful karma, receiving the bitter retributions of consciousness, is also like this.

Virtuous Protector, you should know that consciousness is formless, like the bodies possessed by gods and ghosts, and the good and bad obtained from offerings and food, like the suffering and happiness obtained from sin and merit.
Prince MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How does one see the causes of desire?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!
Desire arises from mutual causes, just like the mutual causes of drilling wood to make fire, adding human effort, and then fire is produced.
In this way, desire arises from causes of consciousness and causes of the colors, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects of men and women.
It is like the production of fruit from flowers, with the fruit in the flower but the flower perishing when the fruit is born.
In this way, consciousness is manifested through the body, but when seeking consciousness through the body, the consciousness is not seen.
Consciousness is born from the fruits of karma, and the body then perishes and disappears, with all the impure things such as the body's bones and marrow dissolving and dispersing.
It is also like a seed holding and bringing the future fruit's flavor, color, smell, and texture, which are transplanted and grow.
Consciousness abandons this body and takes the good and evil karma, perception, conception, and intention to receive the retribution of the next life, and it is the same.
It is also like a man and woman who love each other and part after their union.

Consciousness and the body come together, clinging to each other with love and attachment, and when the retribution is exhausted, they separate and receive retribution according to karma. The parents' conditions and the intermediate existence face each other, and by the power of karma, consciousness obtains the body as the result.
Love and karma are both formless, and desire arises from the characteristics of form and color. This is the cause of desire.
Great Medicine!
How do you see the cause of grasping at precepts?
Precepts refer to the precepts set by the teacher, such as not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not lying, not drinking alcohol, and so forth.
Grasping refers to grasping at these precepts and forming such views:
Because of upholding these precepts, one will attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, and the fruit of non-returning.
Because of this cause, one will obtain a superior existence, referring to receiving a human, heavenly, or other body.
These are all contaminated wholesome [actions], not uncontaminated wholesome [actions]. Uncontaminated wholesome [actions] have no aggregates and ripened fruits.
Now, this grasping at precepts and practices is a type of contaminated seeds, planted in consciousness, which rewards good and bad karma.
Consciousness is not pure and clean, because of the causes of afflictions, one experiences the suffering of heat and distress. This is called the cause of grasping at precepts and practices.
Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
How does consciousness take on a heavenly body, up to taking on a hellish body?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!
Consciousness and the Dharma realm hold subtle vision, not relying on the physical eye as the cause for seeing.
This subtle vision, in conjunction with the realm of blessings, sees the heavenly palaces, desires, pleasures, and frolicking. Having seen this, consciousness becomes attached, thinking like this:
'I should go there.'
Attachment and longing thoughts become the cause for existence.
Seeing one's former body lying in the place of discarded corpses, one thinks like this:
'This corpse is my great good and wise advisor. Because of the accumulation of good karma, it has allowed me to now obtain the heavenly reward.'

Even if the body is as solid as vajra, it can still penetrate the body of a strong man, and can it hold what is equal to the strength of nine elephants?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

It is like the wind element, which has no substance and no form, but when it stops in a secluded valley or a crack, its emergence is violent and fierce, and it can topple Mount Sumeru and crush it into dust.
Great Medicine!
What is the color and appearance of the wind element of Mount Sumeru?
Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
The wind element is subtle, without substance or form.
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!
The wind element is subtle, without substance or form.
Consciousness is also like this, subtle and formless, yet it can hold both large and small bodies, either receiving a mosquito's body or an elephant's body.
It is like a bright lamp, its flame subtle and placed in a room, removing all darkness according to the room's size.
Consciousness is also like this, according to various karmic causes, it holds large and small bodies.
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana said to the Buddha,
World-Honored One!
What are the characteristics and natures of various karmas?
What causes and conditions make them manifest?
The Buddha said,
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana!
Being born in the heavenly palaces, eating heavenly delicacies, and enjoying peace and happiness, all come from the results of one's karma.
It is like a thirsty person wandering in the wilderness. One obtains cool and delicious water, while the other does not obtain anything and suffers from thirst.

The one who obtains the cool water is not given by anyone, and the one who suffers from thirst is not obstructed from being given water. Each receives the karmic retribution of suffering and happiness according to their karmic causes.
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana!
One should see good and evil karma like the white and black halves of the moon in the sky, and like a raw fruit that changes color when the fire element increases and it ripens.

In this way, due to the increase of blessings, this body is born in a noble family, with abundant wealth and overflowing gold and treasures, and with prominent and prosperous characteristics, or is born in the palaces of the gods with blissful and independent joy. All of these are the manifestations of the blessings of good karma.
It is like planting seeds in the ground, with the fruits appearing at the top of the tree.

However, the seeds do not enter from the branches to the top of the tree. Even if one analyzes the body of the tree, one still does not see the seeds. No one holds the seeds and places them on the branches. Even if the tree's roots are firm and one seeks for the seeds, they are not seen.
In this way, all good and evil karma depend on the body, but even if one seeks for karma in the body, one still does not see it.

It is like how, due to the seeds, there are flowers, but the flowers do not contain the seeds. Due to the flowers, there are fruits, but the flowers do not contain the fruits. Even if the flowers and fruits progress, the progress is not seen.
It is the same as how, due to the body, there is karma, and due to karma, there is the body. The body does not contain karma, and karma does not contain the body.
Just as when a flower matures and falls, its fruit then appears, so when the body matures and perishes, the fruits of karma emerge.
It is like having seeds, the causes of flowers and fruits.
In the same way, if there is a body, the causes of good and evil karma are all in that karma, without form and also without the appearance of maturity.

It is like a person's shadow, without substance and unobstructed, cannot be grasped or held, and does not bind or attach to a person, yet advances and retreats, coming and going, following the person's movements, and also does not see the shadow coming out from the body.
The body of karma is also like this, having a body and having karma, but not seeing karma, bound to the body and also not leaving the body, yet able to have karma.
It is like bitter, astringent, and pungent medicinal herbs, which can cleanse the body and remove all illnesses, causing the body to be nourished and the complexion to be radiant.

Those who see a person will know that they have taken good medicine. The taste of the medicine can be taken, but the mature effect has no form, cannot be seen by the eyes, and cannot be grasped, yet it can nourish a person's skin and complexion.
Karma, though formless and substantial, can nourish the body in the same way.

Those nourished by good karma have abundant and beautiful food, clothing, and other necessities, with well-proportioned hands and feet and a beautiful appearance. Their houses are luxurious, filled with maá¹‡i jewels, gold, silver, and various treasures. They are peaceful, happy, and joyful, and their minds are content. Know that this is the characteristic of good karma.

Those born in low, poor border regions lack necessities and envy the happiness of others. Their food and drink are coarse and sometimes they cannot eat. Their appearance is shabby and their dwelling is humble. Know that this is the characteristic of bad karma.
It is like a clear mirror reflecting a face, whether beautiful or ugly. The mirror image has no substance and cannot be grasped.
In the same way, consciousness, nourished by good or bad karma, is born among humans, gods, or in the realms of hell, animals, and so forth.
Great Medicine, you should see karma and consciousness as combining to transform in this way.
Great Medicine said:
World-Honored One!
How can such a subtle consciousness hold the faculties and grasp a large body?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!
It is like a hunter entering the mountains and forests, holding a bow and poisoned arrows to shoot a fragrant elephant.

The poison from the arrow contaminates the blood, and the poison spreads throughout the elephant's body, paralyzing its limbs and faculties, and the poison flows to the vital points, causing the elephant's body to turn blue and red,
like congealed blood. The poison kills the elephant and then immediately departs.
What do you think?
Can the poison and the elephant's body be compared in terms of size and quantity?
Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The size and quantity of the poison and the elephant's body are vastly different and cannot be compared, just like Mount Sumeru compared to a mustard seed.
Great Medicine!
In the same way, consciousness abandons this body and takes on the faculties, abandoning these elements and transmigrating according to karma, it is also like this.
Great Medicine again said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How can such a subtle consciousness support a large body without fatigue?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

Mount Sumeru is 84,000 yojanas high, and the two great dragon kings Nanda and Upananda each encircle it three times. The two dragons' great breaths shake Mount Sumeru, and the water in the inner ocean all turns into poison.
These two dragon kings are long, powerful, and strong, and the two great dragon kings Vasuki and Takshaka are also equal to them.
What do you think?
Are the consciousnesses of the four dragons and the consciousness of a mosquito any different?
Great Medicine said:
World-Honored One!
The consciousnesses of the four dragons and the mosquito are not different.
Great Medicine!
If a small drop of poison enters the mouths of the four dragons, the four dragons will die immediately.
What do you think?
Is the poison in the small drop of medicine or the poison in the dragons' mouths greater?
Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
The poison in a dragon's mouth is great, while the poison in a small drop of medicine is very slight.
Great Medicine!

A being with a large body, the strength of which is equal to that of nine elephants, has a subtle consciousness that is formless and shapeless, not measurable by discrimination. It sustains itself according to karma in the same way.
It is like the seed of a fig tree, extremely tiny, which grows into a tree, vast and spreading, with hundreds of thousands of branches.
What do you think?
Is the size of the seed similar to that of the tree?
Great Medicine said:
World-Honored One!
The size of the seed and the tree differ greatly, like comparing the hole of a lotus thread to the realm of space.
Thus, Great Medicine!
The tree cannot be found in the seed. If it were not for the seed, the tree would not grow.

A tiny fig tree seed can grow into a large tree. A tiny consciousness can produce a large body. The body cannot be found in the consciousness. If it were not for the consciousness, the body would not exist.
Great Medicine further said to the Buddha:
How can the vajra-firm indestructible consciousness abide within a fragile, quickly decaying body?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

It is like a poor person who obtains a wish-fulfilling jewel. By the power of the jewel, lofty mansions, beautifully carved palaces, gardens and forests flourish with flowers and fruits, and elephants, horses, and attendants for entertainment and enjoyment naturally arrive.
Later, the person loses the wish-fulfilling jewel, and all the resources and pleasures disappear.
The wish-fulfilling divine jewel is firm and solid, and even a thousand vajras cannot destroy it. The resources it produces are illusory, impermanent, quickly scattered, and quickly disappear.
Consciousness is also like this, firm and indestructible, while the body it produces quickly decays and disappears.
Great Medicine said:
World-Honored One!
How can the soft and subtle consciousness penetrate into the coarse and hard form?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!
The essence of water is extremely soft, yet rushing streams and waterfalls can penetrate mountains and rocks.
What do you think?
How hard or soft are the qualities of water and stone?

They also saw the gods in lotus palaces, surrounded by beautiful women laughing and playing, with various ornaments such as flower earrings, silk garments, arm bracelets, and anklets. The flowers were always blooming and all the necessary things were provided.

Seeing the heavenly maidens, their minds became attached and affectionate. They were delighted and pleased, with expressions of joy, faces like lotus flowers, and unconfused gazes. Their noses were not crooked, their breath did not smell, and their eyes were bright like blue lotus leaves. There was no pain in their joints, and no blood flowed from their eyes, ears, nose, or mouth. They did not lose urine or feces, their pores did not appear hairy, the palms of their hands were not yellow, their nails were not blue-black, and their hands and feet were not disordered or curled up. World-Honored One!

The realm of karma is subtle. It experiences happiness and receives heavenly food and drink.

Like the dark fortnight and the bright fortnight, good and evil should be seen.
It is like a raw fruit that, when ripe, turns into a different color, but that color is caused by the abundance of fire energy that ripens it.
In the same way, this body, due to the power of blessings, is born into a wealthy and noble family, with abundant wealth and treasures, and presently experiences happiness.
In the heavenly palace, it manifests and experiences heavenly happiness.
Afterwards, when it loses the power of heavenly freedom, it immediately manifests the power of lack of blessings.

It is like a seed planted in the ground, after the tree grows the seed does not appear in the tree, it does not move from branch to branch, it does not appear inside the tree, and no one holds that seed and places it in the tree, it does not move from the root.

In the same way, these good and bad actions, though dwelling within the body, do not appear.
It is like from a seed then there is a flower, from the flower then there is a fruit.
The flower is not in the seed, the fruit is also not in the flower, the fruit and flower have no two separate bodies.
In the same way, these actions within this body exist, from action there is a body, the body is not in the action and can be seen, the action is not in the body and can be seen.

In the same way, when the body matures, the actions can be seen.
Just as wherever there are seeds, there are flowers, and after there are flowers, there are fruits.
In the same way, wherever this body is born, there one sees good and evil, and then there are manifestations. However, those karmic roots are formless.
Just as a person has a shadow due to the body, but that shadow is indeterminate and formless, and still follows the person.
But that shadow does not rely on the person, nor is it separate from the body that the shadow can be seen.
In the same way, the manifestations of good and evil within this body follow without separation, and wherever the body goes, it follows and goes there.
That karma follows everywhere, that karma is not separate from the body, nor is it separate from the body that karma can be manifested.
Just as various medicines, whether pungent, sweet, or bitter, when drunk by a person can cure various illnesses.
Having cured the body of all evils, it makes it soft and manifests a good complexion.
The people who see him can know his appearance, that this person's body has encountered sweet medicine.
However, those medicines have no color in terms of taste and power. Their taste, power, and color cannot be manifested, but only his body's upright appearance can be manifested.

It is just like this. This good karma has no form but reaches the human body. Because of eating delicious food and wearing fine clothes, the person's faculties are complete, and the body experiences happiness.
Moreover, this body is adorned with gold, silver, and precious treasures, and has wealth, nobility, and power. All of these are the realms of good karma.

Those who lack power and have no meritorious karma are poor, suffering, and far from wealth. They are always lacking and seek other people's things. It is just like a bright mirror, because of its brightness, the features of the face, whether beautiful or ugly, are clearly and distinctly reflected, yet the shadow within the mirror has no color.
In the same way, due to the power of good and evil, this consciousness manifests in the human realm, or in the hells, hungry ghost realm, or animal realm.
Great Medicine!
These karmic actions follow this consciousness.
Great Medicine!
You should know and see in this way.

World-Honored One!

It is like a hunter entering a deep mountain forest, holding a strong bow, and then taking poison to smear on the arrowhead to shoot a great elephant.

That drop of poison is extremely small, and the elephant's body is extremely large.

The poison is extremely small, and the elephant's body is like Mount Sumeru.

In this way, when this consciousness abandons the body, it abandons the faculties and the elements, and the sequence is also like this.

World-Honored One!
How can one accept such a vast body without fear?

It is like Mount Sumeru, 84,000 yojanas high, and there are two dragon kings on that mountain:

It is like the seed of a nyagrodha tree. Although its form is small, it can accomplish a large tree, with long and wide branches covering hundreds of thousands of square feet.

yet the shadow is not disturbed.
